question: (a) State four roles of government in agricultural production (b) Describe four traditional land ownership system in Nigeria and give one disadvantage of each system.
answer:
(a) Four roles of government in agricultural production are:

(i) Provision of financial assistance in form of loans and credit facilities to farmers

(ii) Establishment of agricultural programmes such as Farm Settlement Scheme, Green Revolution, Operation feed the Nation, etc.

(iii) Provision of farm inputs such as fertilizers, farm tools and implements, seeds, agro chemicals etc.

(iv) Provision of basic amenities like pipe borne water, electricity and hospital in rural areas.

(b) four traditional systems of land ownership in Nigeria and their disadvantages are :

(i) Communal and Tenure System: The land belongs to the community and only members of the family can have may not have access to the use of such land. Disadvantages: (1) Mechanization may be difficult. (2) Non-members of the community may not have access to the use of the land.

(ii) Land tenure by Inheritance: This is a situation where land is inherited from one's parents. Disadvantage: It leads to land fragmentation

(iii) Lease hold system: This requires the payment of a fee or tenancy for land used over a stated period of time. Disadvantage: The farmer cannot use the land s as collateral security.

(iv) Purchase: This is the total acquisition of land for a fee. Disadvantage: Ownership may be challenged or difficult to establish

question: Discuss eight maintenance practices including the precautions you would take to keep the tractor operating safely and ensure its durability.
answer:
Eight maintenance practices and precautions which can be taken to keep a tractor operating safely and ensure durability after use are:-

(i) Inspect the tractor before starting everyday. It helps to spot potential machine failures and safety hazards.  

(ii)Ensure that nuts and screws or metal parts are tight. Loose nuts, screws and metal parts may cause vibration and produce irritating noise and in some cases may cause machine failure.

(iii) Keep the machine clean by removing all  thrash or mud and excess grease/oil from machine at the start or at the end of operation.

(iv) Do not overload the tractor i.e. operate at appropriate speed for field operations and avoid using it under conditions that are unfavourable.

(v) Employ a skilled or competent and experienced tractor operator.

(vi) Carry out routine services by changing filters and oil when due.

(vii) Check water and oil levels regularly to ensure that they are normal and to prevent any overheating or seizure of engine.

(viii) Check tyre pressures and replace flat or worn-out tyres.

question: Describe briefly the side effects of preventive and control measures of method diseases and pests of crops under the following headings: (a) chemical control (b) biological control (c) cultural of control .
answer:
The side effects of various preventive and control measures of diseases and pests of crops are:

(a) Chemical method of control:

(i) Almost all the chemicals used are toxic to man and domestic animals.

(ii) Some beneficial insects of soil organisms may be destroyed.

(iii) Pests and diseases may develop resistance to chemical. (iv) Some chemicals may cause water pollution.

(v) Empty containers could be a source of poison when used as containers for consumables.

(b) Biological method of control:

(i) The new organisms introduced may start attacking crops which were formerly free from attack.

(ii) The predators introduced may feed on other beneficial insects causing imbalance in the ecosystem.

(c) Cultural method of control:

(i) The use of fire may spread to other farms

(ii) The use of fire may kill some beneficial organisms.

(iii) It can lead to destruction and losses of organic matter in the soil.

(iv) It can also destroy the soil structure

question: a) Describe briefly five management methods adopted in the forest area to ensure a continuous timber supply. (b) Enumerate six benefits derived from forestry and range
answer:
(a) Five management methods adopted in the forest areas to ensure a continuous timber supply are:

(i) Forest Regulations : These are laws made by the government to conserve or preserve forest trees. No person can cut down timber without government permission.

(ii) Selective exploration: Forest trees can be cut down while allowing others to reach maturity before they too are cut

(iii) Afforestation: This is the planting of new trees to replace the ones that have been cut.

(iv) Fire prevention: This prevents annual bush burning and where possible, establishes fire breaks.

(v) Taungya system : This system allows the farmer to plant his crops after which they will plant economic trees on the same piece of land.

(b) Six benefits derived from forestry and range are:

(i) Supply of food such as fruits, seeds. bush meat, etc.

(ii) Supply of fuel (fire wood). (iii) Provision of timber for furniture and buildings.

(iv) Provision of employment to some people. (v) Forest is a source of medicinal herbs.

(vi) Provision of pulpwood for paper making.

question: Explain briefly the following terms: (a). ovulation; (b) oestrus cycle; (c) gestation (d) parturition
answer:
(a) Ovulation : This is the rupturing of the ovary wall to release mature eggs (ova) or ovum into the oviduct of the female animal. It is under the control of the pituitary gland and it occurs in between oestrus cycle.

(b) Oestrus cycle : This is the interval from the end of one heat period to the beginning of another. It is the period of heat in farm animals and it is controlled by a hormone. It varies from one animal to another, e.g. Cow = 20 - 21 days; Ewe = 7 -21 days; Sow --- 14 - 28 days .

(c) Gestation:This is the time between conception and birth, during which the embryo or fetus is developing in the uterus

(d) Parturition : This is the act of giving birth in farm animals. It marks the end of pregnancy and the beginning of lactation. The act of giving birth in Cow - Calving, Sow - Farrowing, Ewe - Lambing, Doe (Goat) Kidding.

question: a) What is balanced ration ? (b) If birds at point of lay were fed a ration/feed containing: maize meal - 65°/ , groundnut cake - 25%, fish meal - 5% and brewers' grain - 5%. Name the other feed ingredients that are essential which are not listed. State the importance of the ingredients you have listed.
answer:
(a) Balance ration is the feed containing all essential nutrients in the correct amount and adequate proportion for feeding animals.

(b) Essential ingredients not included are: (i) Oyster shell or bone meal (ii) Fats and oil (iii) Mineral salts (iv) Vitamin or vitamin supplement.

(c) Importance of the ingredients listed above include:

(i) Oyster shell or bone meal:

(1) Farm animals need calcium and phosphorus for bone and teeth development.

(2) Birds need calcium and phosphorus for egg shell formation.

(3) It also supplies other essential minerals like sodium, copper, etc for osmotic balance

(ii) Fats and oil:

(1) It provides carotene rich in vitamin A.

(2) It provides an additional source of energy

(3) It is required for good egg yolk formation.

(4) It prevents dustiness in feed.

(iii) Mineral salt:

(1) Salt improves palatability of feed.

(2) It supplies sodium as sodium chloride.

(3) It is useful for enzymatic functions in intestinal tract.

(iv) Vitamins or vitamin supplements:

(1) They provide the necessary vitamin requirements.

(2) They are necessary for good egg formation.

(3) They are necessary for good bone formation.

question: (a) Explain agricultural marketing and four channels of marketing farm produce. (b) State four problems associated With marketing of farm produce by small-scale farmers.
answer:
(a)(i) Agricultural marketing involves ail the activities re-quired to move farm produce from the producers (farmers) to the final consumers.

(ii) Channels of marketing farm produce are:

(1) Local markets where sellers and buyers are in close contact.

(2) Cooperative Societies which facilitate the flow of bulk sales and enhance the bargaining power of farmers.

(3) Commissioned agents who buy directly from the farmers in bulk and sell to marketing boards and exporters.

(4) Exporters who sell the commodities to overseas buyers (consumers).

(b) Four problems associated with marketing of farm produce by small scale farmers are:

(i) Inadequate stor-age facilities

(ii) Produce are perishable.

(iii) Transportation is grossly inadequate.

(iv) Poor prices of products.

question: List six environmental factors affecting agricultural production in Nigeria. (b) Explain briefly how five of the factors listed in (a) can affect agricultural production in Nigeria
answer:
(a) Six environmental factors affecting agricultural production in Nigeria are (i) Rainfall (ii) Temperature (iii) Wind (iv) Parasites (v) Pests and diseases (vi) Light/sunshine

(b) Agricultural production in Nigeria can be affected by:

(a) Rainfall (1) It is necessary for seed germination. (2) It ensures availability of nutrient to plants by dissolving it. (3) It affects the distribution of plants and animals. (4) Excessive rainfall may cause soil erosion.

(b) Wind: (1) It increases the rate of transpiration in crops. (2) High wind velocity may cause wind erosion. (3) It aids seed dispersal. (4) It aids pollination of flowers.

(c) Light/sunshine: (1) It is necessary for photosynthesis. (2) It affects evapo-transpiration in crops. (3) Some crops exhibit photoperiodism

(d) Parasites: (1) They transmit diseases. (2) They may kill host animals and plants. (3) They reduce the quantity and quality of crops or livestock.

(e) Pests and diseases: (1) They reduce the quality and quantity of crops and livestock. (2) They decrease the farmers' profit. (3) They transmit diseases from one crop to another.

question: State the law of demand and six basic assumptions as related to agricultural products. Illustrate your answer with the aid of a demand schedule and a demand curve
answer:
(a) The law of demand states that the lower the price, the more or higher the quantity of agricultural produce that will be demanded or the higher the price, the lower the quantity of produce that will be demanded.

(b) Six basic assumptions as related to agricultural products are that:

(i) No very close substitutes for commodity exist.

(ii) There is no change in tastes and preference of the consumers.

(iii) The amount of money or income of the consumers remain constant.

(iv) There is no change in the quality of products.

(v) The habits of consumers remain unchanged.

(vi) The prices of other goods remain constant.
